description: Concatenation of n consecutive descending numbers starting from a(n) produces the smallest possible prime of this form, 0 if no such prime exists.
comments: First hard cases occur for n = 22, 88 and 110.a(22) = 10^1631 + 10 was found by _James G. Merickel_ in Feb 2011.a(88) = 10^14 + 6.a(110) = 10^19 + 26 was found by Chris Nash.
example: For n = 8 we have a(8) = 46 so the eight consecutive descending numbers 46,45,44,43,42,41,40 and 39 concatenated together gives the smallest possible prime of this form, 4645444342414039.
author: _Patrick De Geest_, Jan 15 2000
extensions: Terms a(7)-a(21) calculated by _Carlos Rivera_ and _Felice Russo_
